threads.com:
/vrpg/ is a place to discuss all types of role-playing video games, including single-player, multi-player, and massively multi-player, turn-based and real-time action, western-style and JRPG.

Does this mean RPGs are banned on other video game boards? No! /vrpg/ is just a separate board specifically focused on RPGs where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vrpg/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2861075
>Cmon guys, can't we be a bit more intelectually honest in our anticlericalism?
1. It's a fictional world with with fictional non-human races, fictional magical metaphysics and a fictional Polytheistic religion that is distinctly not Christianity. All it borrows from Christianity are aesthetics and a Reformation-like internal political conflict.

2. The religion specifically and the culture in general as they are presented in the game are not exactly in their top shape - the game's full title is "The life and suffering of Sir Brante IN THE TIMES OF THE FALL OF THE BLESSED ARKNIAN EMPIRE". The church is not meant to be so messed up, the nobles are not supposed to be so cruel, the life is not supposed to be so hard in the Arknian Empire - but the plot is focused on the period of the greatest crisis in it's history, and specifically focuses on how said crisis amplifies the strife between people and turns them to worst. This is not "fantasy HRE as it simply is", it's "HRE during the Bohemian Revolt", or "China during the Warlord Era", or "US during the Civil War". Even then - when Brante comes to the Capital in his youth and encounters a religious protest, the Inquisition reacts peacefully, by engaging protestors in a debate. In actually takes Brante going as an orthodox inquisitor for the Old Faith to start kicking ass and burning heretics, otherwise they are just blundering and ineffective.

3. You can play as a conservative nobleman or an orthodox priest, call names, kick ass, burn heretics and make titles - and you'll be great for it and nobody will call you out on it. It's a valid and reasonable way to play - the game goes to great lengths to point out that nobody is actually all-around good, and every approach comes with downsides even if you execute it perfectly.

I can't really enjoy rpgs where each session I have isn't challenging and full of active, efficient gameplay. pic related does it right but they should've had an arcade mode where you get all the gear you want at the shops (no farming needed)

Most rpgs fail to do this and are full of dead air and even their hard parts aren't structured well, your party wipes you can just keep retrying there's very little consequence or feeling of loss which makes victory less satisfying

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Looting in warpigs:
>finish a battle
>individually search each and every enemy's corpse and click "take all" along with collecting random bits of cutlery and other garbage littering the room
>become overburdened with useless vendor trash that only exists to be sold
>spend the next few minutes figuring out how to most efficiently distribute the weight between your party, changing equipment to maximise strength bonuses as you do
>head to town to sell everything, making sure to give it all to the party member with the highest barter skill first
>go back to get the rest of the loot
>turns out the merchant doesn't have enough money to buy everything

Looting in jarpigs:
>finish battle
>results screen shows any items you automatically looted, which you can usually carry with effectively no limit
>that's it

Why is it still like this? I'm not even trying to go full weeb and say jarpigs are totally superior, there are definitely things warpigs do better but this isn't one of them. Seriously, why do encumbrance mechanics even still exist? They can't be for realism because they're usually generous enough to let you carry way more than you ever could in reality, and they aren't there as a strategic constraint on the amount of resources you can carry because consumables are typically light and make up maybe 20% of the total weight at most. I like inventory limits in survival horror and some other genres but in any RPG where looting is a major component of the gameplay they need to go, unless maybe the game is really trying hard to be at least somewhat realistic.

threads.com: this isn't about deus ex vs. fallout, just the inventory system. i like that with a grid you can see everything at once instead of scrolling through a list and having 5 different lists, but only having 30 different spaces means you can't carry a large variety of items. with a list, there can be lots of different things with very small weights, like ammo. each round has a low weight but it adds up realistically, so you can decide if you want to carry a variety of calibers or just a ton of ammo for one gun you like. in deus ex, you have absolute ammo limits like 150 10mm rounds. i know human revolution's grid has smaller spaces and more of them, which means ammo can be kept in the main inventory, but in that when you have a lot of ammo of one type it clutters your grid because it only stacks up to 50 rounds in a box so you'll have ten boxes of the same thing all over your inventory, so i like the deus ex 1 grid more. STALKER is a weird case because it's limited by weight but displays things on a grid with infinite spaces. i never liked that because you still carry a lot of different items like artifacts, ammo types, and every duplicate weapon still appears in a new space instead of ak-74 (x3) or something. so all that combined with items having images and everything being in one category means your inventory can be so visually cluttered you have to scroll way down to find something even if you're way under the weight limit. i don't hate it, it's just a little weird. it probably comes down to the complexity of the game. like i was saying, lists can do small objects and an infinite variety of things but for an action game the grid being simpler and faster to look through is better.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I prefer grid inventory simply because they are smaller. I find it obnoxious how games are filled with junk you pick up accidentally or by taking all and then somewhere down the line you have to throw it away.
Granted nothing stops anyone from making a game with list-based inventory that doesn't do that, but I don't remember any game with list inventory which didn't result in my inventory filling with junk, suddenly making it impossible to pick more while not offering really meaningful decision-making because they overflowed from junk and not from potentially useful things.

The problem is that none of that shit ends up being Star Trek in the end. We already have games trying to ape Star Trek's look while implementing a few core and solid ideas like gamedev 101 says you should do.

They end up being not Star Trek ultimately. Star Trek wasn't a gameified experience. One episode could be a legal drama over the ethics of corporate ownership over AI while the next episode could be a conventional shoot-em-up on an alien planet. You can't adapt that into a game. You can get games that adapt *some* of those elements well, but no game ever will capture what Star Trek was in game form. It's just not possible and it never will be possible.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Game inspired by Victorian adventure novels and Méliès' A Trip to the Moon.
You're a precocious young child who stows away aboard a craft to be sent to Mars and accidentally launch it. When you get to Mars you are confronted by the Kingdom of Mars and are unable to communicate with them.
Some react with hostility, some with curiosity, and others with fear, but it can be hard to tell the difference because of the language barrier.
You can easily kill them with your umbrella because they are very weak of constitution compared to you, and you can make a beeline for their capital, kill their king, and proclaim yourself King of Mars. This can be done relatively easily, and by the end, Mars will be a colony of whatever nation you've chosen as your origin.
The other main option is to figure out how to communicate with them which will eventually lead you into an existing narrative involving the kingdom's politics and domestic & foreign issues.
More or less, one path is Robinson Crusoe and the other, Barsoom.
But the key bit is that the game wouldn't judge you for your choices. The morality of the game would be of the colonial era, and butchering a bunch of Martians would all be framed as a triumph of the human will in a new age of discovery. There would be as much self-awareness here as there is in 20,000 Leagues when the crew of the Nautilus electrocutes a bunch of cannibals.
I'd like the choices to be less binary of course. Even if you decide to go native, you're still aligning yourself with one faction and acting out of a sense of moral objectivity. The question is just how much effort you're willing to put in to learn about this culture and how that knowledge will affect your actions.

Doing 0 stealth on the very first playthrough is pretty daring. But your plan for the area should still be not getting noticed rather than trying to fight your way through, even on Tough personality.
You can get some bonus SCU from equipment (hobo clothes and/or face paint) and by keeping Lona dirty, which makes a bit of difference in how fast/easily you get noticed. You can still distract thugs with a rock throw or lead them around with a sequence of rock throws. threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: What is the correct mindset to enjoy DRPGs?
threads.com:
I've tried playing some DRPGs and there's a lot of things I like about them:
>party management
>free character creation, allowing for a multitude of approaches
>first person exploration is usually immersive
>I like drawing maps and making my own notes

Even though I like all these things, there's one thing that always filters me in these games: the combat. No matter how much I try, it seems that all the DRPGs really on two types of battles: the ones where you mash attack until the enemy is dead without worrying about anything and the ones where you try to mash attack to win but the enemy completely destroys your whole party with just one attack. This second option usually becomes a RNG fest, because while the enemy always has this attack that wipes your party, it can use it on turn 1, turn 10 or never use it, so it all comes down to luck.
So, what you do to enjoy this? Do you just accept that combat is shit and decide to have a good time with the remaining characteristics of the game?

>>2853833
>Drops you directly into an open world with no backstory or character info
I have a huge problem with this. I would take almost every other point of this Greentext if the game actually took the effort of trying to convey common world knowledge to the player when it's expected the character had been living there for ages. I find it really weird when I make a character with the idea "oh he's from over there" and then I meet people from over there and they couldn't be any similar at all and there's no way to reconcile these differences. You remember the Dark Souls default character faces?
>Astora Royalty
>Jubilant Catarina
>Dubious Carim
This shit makes me hard. It tells you what kind of places there are, what kinds of people leave those places, and what they look like, to get you to better fit in with them by the time you get to see any of them firsthand. This can also serve to flavor a character beyond its raw mechanics before you even get to the items that make your character a build. Rogues are dubious little creatures, so no stretch of imagination is required to see that Dubious Carim would fit any sleuthy Dexterity focused characters. Jubilant Catarina's goofy face is one thing, but to be known for festivity and drink explains the reckless and daring strategies such as running around naked with a huge Strength weapon.

That's all a game really needs; an optional suggestion during character creation that, even if you don't take it, tells you what a "normal" setting-fitting character looks like.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Daggerfall requires a lot of effort on the player to enjoy. A lot of suspension of disbelief. But if you allow yourself to be fooled, it is actually a very fun game. Even though every quest and city is procedurally generated, after you've been playing for a while you kind of allow the illusion that every location is unique to grow on you. You get a sense of scale and realism that no other RPG offers.

I remember Zaric saying that every region in Daggerfall felt unique to him. I thought this was nonsense. How could a region feel unique when it uses the exact same generation algorithm as every other generic region in the game? I didn't understand this until I properly played Daggerfall and gave it a chance rather than dismissing it as procedurally generated garbage like I had done before. For example, over time you remember certain town layouts, you find a city with all the right services that your character requires in the one place, or you grow fond of a city that you've done a lot of quests in. And after a while of helping people out you see your reputation in a region has grown, it feels good that your actions in this world actually mean something.

Daggerfall definitely has something that no other RPG I've played has. A sense of immersion that you really are just an itinerant adventurer living in a fantasy world. Even though it's from 1996 it feels surprisingly modern in the amount of freedom it gives you.

Of course, the Unity version and shit ton of mods help a lot too. There are a lot of quest and world overhaul mods so the game doesn't feel so samey all the time.

Not trying to sound elitist, but the design of the Bethesda era Fallout games are geared to sell and to sell to the lowest common demoninator. The level design is simple - open flat fields and any interior is just some simple easy to navigate building. You can't get lost. And you are given a god-mode "press a button and kill an enemy for free" button called VATS. The illusion of choice - where you're build isn't as important as your level and any random set of perks will more or less make you strong end-game, are also by design. It's so you can't screw up making a character.

If you were to try to "fix" these issues, then you'd cut into sales and you can't have that.

I just finished this game last night including beating Anise and have to say what a game, what a remake. It perfectly encapsulates the meaning of the word FUN just like Seiken Densetsu 3 does on the SFC. I chose Duran, Angela and Riesz. I went with Liege, Fenrir Knight and Magus before class 4 upgrades. This worked out perfectly as I had party healing with Duran and ancient curse and hexas from the ladies wiped enemies off the screen at ease.

I have to give a standing ovation to Angela’s VA as she captured perfectly what a quintessential female video game character should be. I love how extremely feminine and loveable Angela is from beginning to end, she oozes sex appeal in a way I didn’t think video game characters could. Women take notes, this is how you drive a man crazy and capture his heart for life. Even if you are a transgender person play this game and copy exactly Angela’s mannerism and you will still find love and happiness. I am new to Riesz and I was completely shocked by just how poignant her character story is. It’s a simple story but extremely well written and animated. If you have her in your party, do not skip it. Something about the saddened expression on her face, on her serious and well-meaning personality, it will really get you. As a man it struck me to the core, made me want to step up as a man, drop everything and support her cause.

Some flaws, a few boss designs were far from perfect, many told me this was too easy and it is until you have to face zehnoa, which becomes impossible to beat on a hard setting without getting pissed off. I’m still convinced that boss is a game glitch.

I would love to play more games like this, but I do not know if they exist

….. I’m a little bit shocked and saddened by the number of Riesz haters in the thread. Yes she wasn’t my fav on the SFC, it was always Duran, Angela and Kevin for me. But I can confirm I have zero regrets about picking her over Kevin’s melee abilities, and would do so again in a heartbeat. Her summon Hexas was just as powerful as Angel’s best spell Ancient Curse (which is, again by far Angela’s best spell and in a class of its own) and the debuff spells were extremely valuable in boss fights. I will stick to my lonely opinion that her character story is very good. Allow me to explain:

Riesz’s story is simple, it could be explained in a brief sentence and the story will not sound particularly special to anybody. However it was extremely well written because it throws at the audience the most genuine feelings I have come across in a video game. The way Bill and Ben lied to Riesz’s younger brother Elliot about what his dead mom said in order to get what they want, is vile. I felt a strong feeling of negative and disgusting energy just from sitting through this part. Lying to an innocent kid who wants to see his dead mom…. Pic fucking related. How could you not be flushed in anger at such a disgusting act? If you think this writing is shit then you have not wrestled with the tensions and vengefulness that exists in Riesz’s character. To top it off Riesz is obviously the more serious character, you can easily tell by the contrasting one liners she says after battles, as opposed to Angela’s light hearted sayings. She faces the journey with the heaviest burden out of all 6 characters by far. Still, Riesz radiates as a good helpful soul, despite being extremely down in her luck. For fuck’s sake Riesz’s class 4 item is called the Kind sphere. Sorry but I won’t let you say that Riesz’s story is the worst. If anything Duran’s story, who is also an orphan himself, came across as much more vapid in comparison

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
What about level scaling?

In Dragon Quest your hero typically gains an average of say 3 str and 7 hp per level. That is fine. But if you start out level 1 with 6 str and 14 hp, that is a 50% improvement in both categories. Once you are around level 21 with 66 str and 154 hp, gaining that next level of +3 str and + 7 hp average is now only a 5% improvement. I know that most of the games have points where gains are increased temporarily but even then it is like +5 str and +11 hp. In Dragon Quest games leveling tends to not improve your character much the further you level outside of learning new spells.

A lot of Final Fantasy games scale better where by level 10 you are earning 20 hp per level and then by level 60 you are earning 100 to 150 per level. Strength tends to stay consistent in raw numbers when leveling up (usually +1 to 3), but 255 str may do 9999, with 205 str doing 7000. That is 3000 damage gained by 50 points. Whereas in the beginning going from 10 str to 60 str may improve your attack from 30 to 500. The same +50 str only nets you 470 extra damage early game instead of 3000.

I know each FF game uses different formulas but I kind of just made up a basic mockup. On paper I think I would prefer FF but in practice i like DQs better.

RPGs are about immersion, story, exploring game both from point of view of world/story building and mechanically. Ultimately, how "hard" or "grindy" pure rpg is depends really on how much time you put into researching system, exploring world for resources and grinding.

Now, issue is when we start grabbing for hybrid genres like Action Rpgs. Then it really depends on how much game is leaning on player's input over stats and numbers.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Don't ask me how but I got to play part of FF7Rebirth and I am anonymously breaking my NDA for the greater good.

I don't speak Japanese but here's what I could discern:

- Tetsuya Nomura makes a cameo as a villager and his face looks even more baby-like and pudgey than in real life
- Masashi Hamauzu makes an appearance too. When it's time to play the piano, he literally comes out and TEACHES YOU HOW TO PLAY THE PIANO. He karate chops you in the neck if you fuck up and pulls out a sick ass violin as he starts playing that one song from FF13
Dark Jenova is the main antagonist. She's like Jenova, but darker. Melanated.
- Zack lives in Cloud's mind. He's like a schizophrenic huff of crack-cocaine. He lives in his head rent-free.
- The game sets up a spinoff. They're trying to turn this shit into kingdom hearts.
- Masafumi Miyamoto's father takes over Shinra corporation. This is a reference to Kabushiki Gaisha Den-Yu-Sha, an obscure fighting game on the PS1 only visible to Japanese citizens.
- Aerith becomes a hip-hop star. They make it very evident from the game's writing that this was implored by Motomu Toriyama as a callback to Final Fantasy X-2. In fact, he gets downloaded into the game and breaks the fourth wall as he explains to the player that "The prayer is not to be trusted to do things rike wandering around the town. They shourd shit down and shut arp as we terr our story rike a mobie.", in English, as I do not speak Japanese.
- Angeal and Genesis join your party, but both of their faces have been replaced with Hironobu Sakaguchi's. I suspect that they had him take some 3D shots at the secretly re-opened Square Pictures studio in Hawaii, as the models strangely very closely resemble Aki Ross despite them being created for two beefy men.

>>2858089
The real issue with the armor system is the way it screws you if you are a mage. On higher difficulties, pretty much every enemy has some elemental resistance with every element. Possibly one element with more than 60 or 70%. So if you want to be let's say, an air mage and an enemy is resistant to air you will pretty much do no damage. And you can't really spec on every single element and expect to deal as much damage as a physical attacker / necromancer because there is no physical resistance.
An archer can just tactical jump to higher ground, buff himself and use Marksman Fang to ignore armor altogether and one shot people later on.
If physical damage was resisted somewhat or split into categories like Pierce/Bash/Slash (and enemies had a resistance stat for those) depending on your equipped weapon and/or skill, it would push players to rethink going full physical damage.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2859232
cont.
Magic damage has just one thing going for it that physical damage doesn't have and that is resistance debuffs. You have ways of making enemies weaker to any elements with thinks like wet, shocked, burning, poisoned, oiled, etc. However, that also brings another problem. Earth and Fire have decent synergy together but neither works well with Water. Water works best with... water. Air is split between Wind spells and Electricity spells. Wind spells are mostly shit and Electricity spells are too expensive AP wise. Both need some Water (wet status) to do any real damage but too much water (frozen status) actually makes enemy more resistant to Air.
The one way I found to make a character who could deal damage with any element and have fun was to make a Wand+Shield Summoner. Cap Vitality and Memory and acquire every summon in the game.
